rocks.bastion.core.json

Class JsonRequest

  • java.lang.Object
    • rocks.bastion.core.json.JsonRequest
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    HttpRequest

    public class JsonRequest
extends Object
implements HttpRequest
    A JSON request for use during Bastion tests. The JSON body is supplied either inline or from a JSON file on the classpath. Automatically sets the correct content type to use. This request will verify that the provided JSON body contains valid JSON. Initially, the request is configured to send "application/json" as its Content-type header but this can be overriden by the user by calling the overrideContentType(ContentType) method.

    • Method Detail

      • fromString

        public static JsonRequest fromString(HttpMethod method,
                                     String url,
                                     String json)
                              throws InvalidJsonException
        Construct an HTTP request containing a JSON body from the given JSON string. Initially, the request will have the "application/json" HTTP header and no other additional headers and no query parameters. It will also have a descriptive name which is generated by combining the HTTP method with the URL.
        Parameters:
        method - The HTTP method to use for this request
        url - The URL to send this request on
        json - The JSON text to send as body content for this request
        Returns:
        An HTTP request containing the specified JSON body text
        Throws:
        InvalidJsonException - Thrown if the specified JSON text is not valid JSON text

      • fromResource

        public static JsonRequest fromResource(HttpMethod method,
                                       String url,
                                       String jsonSource)
                                throws InvalidJsonException,
                                       UnreadableResourceException,
                                       ResourceNotFoundException

        Construct an HTTP request containing a JSON body that is read from the given resource. The resource source is specified as a resource URL as described in ResourceLoader. Valid resource URLs include (but are not limited to):

        • classpath:/rocks/bastion/json/Sushi.json
        • file:/home/user/Sushi.json

        For more information about which resource URLs are accepted see the documentation for ResourceLoader.

        Initially, the request will have the "application/json" HTTP header and no other additional headers and no query parameters. It will also have a descriptive name which is generated by combining the HTTP method with the URL.

        Parameters:
        method - The HTTP method to use for this request
        url - The URL to send this request on
        jsonSource - The source URL to load the JSON text from, for this request
        Returns:
        An HTTP request containing the specified JSON body text
        Throws:
        InvalidJsonException - Thrown if the specified JSON text is not valid JSON text
        UnreadableResourceException - Thrown if the specified resource exists but cannot be read (because it is a directory, for example)
        ResourceNotFoundException - Thrown if the specified resource does not exist

      • fromTemplate

        public static JsonRequest fromTemplate(HttpMethod method,
                                       String url,
                                       String jsonTemplateSource,
                                       Map<String,String> variableAssignments)

        Similar to the fromResource(HttpMethod, String, String) method but also supports template variable replacements. This allows you to store a request template as a JSON file where the template is written using Mustache. Each variable's value is supplied as the variableAssignments parameter in a map. If the template cannot resolve a variable, an exception is thrown.

        The template file is specified as a resource URL as described in ResourceLoader. Valid resource URLs include (but are not limited to):

        • classpath:/rocks/bastion/json/Sushi.json
        • file:/home/user/Sushi.json

        For more information about which resource URLs are accepted see the documentation for ResourceLoader.

        Initially, the request will have the "application/json" HTTP header and no other additional headers and no query parameters. It will also have a descriptive name which is generated by combining the HTTP method with the URL.

        Parameters:
        method - The HTTP method to use for this request
        url - The URL to send this request on
        jsonTemplateSource - The resource URL to load the template file from, for this request
        variableAssignments - The values used when resolving variables in the loaded template
        Returns:
        An HTTP request containing the specified JSON body text
        Throws:
        InvalidJsonException - Thrown if the specified JSON text is not valid JSON text
        UnreadableResourceException - Thrown if the specified resource exists but cannot be read (because it is a directory, for example)
        ResourceNotFoundException - Thrown if the specified resource does not exist
        TemplateCompilationException - Thrown if a variable in the loaded template does not have an assignment in the variableAssignments map

      • postFromTemplate

        public static JsonRequest postFromTemplate(String url,
                                           String jsonTemplateSource,
                                           Map<String,String> variableAssignments)

        Similar to the postFromResource(String, String) method but also supports template variable replacements. This allows you to store a request template as a JSON file where the template is written using Mustache. Each variable's value is supplied as the variableAssignments parameter in a map.         • file:/home/user/Sushi.json

        For more information about which resource URLs are accepted see the documentation for ResourceLoader.

        Parameters:

        jsonTemplateSource - The resource URL to load the template file from, for this request
        variableAssignments - The values used when resolving variables in the loaded template
        Returns:
        An HTTP request containing the specified JSON body text
        Throws:
        InvalidJsonException - Thrown if the specified JSON text is not valid JSON text
        UnreadableResourceException - Thrown if the specified resource exists but cannot be read (because it is a directory, for example)
        ResourceNotFoundException - Thrown if the specified resource does not exist
        TemplateCompilationException - Thrown if a variable in the loaded template does not have an assignment in the variableAssignments map

      • overrideContentType

        public JsonRequest overrideContentType(org.apache.http.entity.ContentType contentType)
        Override the content-type that will be used for this request. Initially, the content-type for a JSONRequest is "application/json" but you can override what is sent using this method.
        Parameters:
        contentType - A content-type to use for this request. Can be null.
        Returns:
        This request (for method chaining)

                             String value)
        Add a new HTTP header that will be sent with this request.
        Parameters:
        name - A non-null name for the new header
        value - A non-null value for the new header
        Returns:
        This request (for method chaining)

      • addQueryParam

        public JsonRequest addQueryParam(String name,
                                 String value)
        Add a new HTTP query parameter that will be sent with this request.
        Parameters:
        name - A non-null name for the new query parameter
        value - A non-null value for the new query parameter
        Returns:
        This request (for method chaining)

      • addRouteParam

        public JsonRequest addRouteParam(String name,
                                 String value)
        Add a new HTTP route parameter that will be sent with this request. Put a placeholder for the route parameter in the request URL by surrounding a parameter's name using braces (eg. http://sushi.test/{id}/ingredients). The URL in the previous example contains one route param which can be replaced with a numerical value using addRouteParam("id", "53"), for example.
        Parameters:
        name - A non-null name for the new route parameter
        value - A non-null value for the new route parameter
        Returns:
        This request (for method chaining)

      • method

        public HttpMethod method()
        Description copied from interface: HttpRequest
        Returns the HTTP method to use for sending this request. Can be one of the constants from HttpMethod or a custom HTTP method which is non-standard.
        Specified by:
        method in interface HttpRequest
        Returns:
        A non-null HTTP method for this request

      • contentType

        public Optional<org.apache.http.entity.ContentType> contentType()
        Description copied from interface: HttpRequest
        The content type header to use for this request. This includes the MIME type of the content body, an optional character set of the request and other parameters, if necessary (such as quality parameter).
        Specified by:
        contentType in interface HttpRequest
        Returns:
        An optional content type to use for this request. Return an empty Optional if you would like to leave the content-type header undefined for this request.

      • headers

        public Collection<ApiHeader> headers()
        Description copied from interface: HttpRequest
        A collection of HTTP headers that will be included with this request. Note that Bastion will automatically include the "Content-type" header using the value returned by HttpRequest.contentType() if, and only if, the collection returned by this method does not contain a header for "Content-type." This means that this method should not return a "Content-type" header as part of the collection unless you want to override the content-type returned by the HttpRequest.contentType() method.
        Specified by:
        headers in interface HttpRequest
        Returns:
        A non-null collection of HTTP header to include with the request

      • queryParams

        public Collection<ApiQueryParam> queryParams()
        Description copied from interface: HttpRequest
        A collection of HTTP query parameters that will be used for performing this request. Query parameters are typically appended to the end of an URL following a question mark symbol.
        Specified by:
        queryParams in interface HttpRequest
        Returns:
        A non-null collection of query parameters for this request

      • routeParams

        public Collection<RouteParam> routeParams()
        Description copied from interface: HttpRequest

        A collection of route parameter assignments that will be replaced in the URL. For example, the following URL:

        http://sushi.test/{id}/ingredients

        The URL above contains one route parameter called "id" which can be assigned a numerical value which will be replaced when the actual HTTP takes place.

        Specified by:
        routeParams in interface HttpRequest
        Returns:
        A non-null collection of route parameters for this request.

      • body

        public Object body()
        Description copied from interface: HttpRequest
        An object that will serve as a content body for this request. Can be null if this request will not send a body. Bastion may use the content-type of this request, returned by the HttpRequest.contentType() method, as well as the runtime type of the object returned by this method to determine how best to serialize the returned object into the HTTP request's body.
        Specified by:
        body in interface HttpRequest
        Returns:
        An object that will serve as the content body for this request. May be null.
